titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, International Division, South and Southeast Asia, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia Field Office Files
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, International Division, South and Southeast Asia, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia Field Office Files FA648

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-03-15 00:31:49 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, International Division, South and Southeast Asia, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia Field Office Files

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in 2 series by file type.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains administrative files and subject files.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation's office in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia operated from between 1962 and 1976. It was responsible for overseeing grants for the countries of Malaysia and Singapore. These grants primarily focused on agricultural and industrial development, higher education and research, management and administration, and population and family planning.

The Ford Foundation established its Kuala Lumpur office in 1962 as part of its efforts to expand its overseas development program in Southeast Asia. The Malay peninsula was considered vital to the long term political and economic development of the region. Before the Malaysia office was opened, the Foundation's Asia program consisted of four country programs in India, Pakistan, Indonesia, and Burma (Myanmar). The Kuala Lumpur Office opened shortly before the Foundation closed its Rangoon, Burma office. Burma Representative Walter A. Rudlin relocated to Malaysia.

In 1968, the Foundation's Malaysia and Singapore programs became absorbed under the Ford Foundation Southeast Asia Regional Office in Bangkok, Thailand. The Kuala Lumpur office later closed in 1976. Several significant events in the history of Malaysia occurred during the time the Foundation had its office there such as the formation of Malaysia from the union of Malaya, North Borneo, Sarawak, and Singapore in 1963, Singapore leaving Malaysia in 1965, and the May 1969 race riots in Kuala Lumpur.
- Information taken from The Ford Foundation in Malaysia information paper, Ford Foundation records, Catalogued Reports, Reports 1-3254 (FA739A), Report 002088
